/* Early career */ removing hidden comment that's dealt with
/* "City in agony" */ Removing "he would have to be Wheaties"; we can't have a link in the quote per MOS. Also, Wheaties doesn't mean anything to most readers.
/* Black Monday */ change title to Assassination. "Black Monday" is vague and not explained nor referenced
/* Race for state assembly */ tighten; per WP:CAPTIONS, captions are tighter than text
/* "Heroic things" */ Adding "Milk's ex-lover" because that information was several sections above
/* Change and politics */ "Change and politics" doesn't grab me; "changing politics" has a nice double meaning ("changing" can be a verb or adjective), but revert if that's too cute
/* Castro Street */ this order is better if the productions overlapped or if Lenny came first; otherwise, I'd go with "then _Lenny_"
/* Change and politics */ allow me to make the typical snotty copyeditor comment: we can see they're organizations, and that there are two of them, and the sentences before and after suggest SF
/* Change and politics */ "suprisingly popular" is okay if you describe why it's suprising, but that might be too much of a detour; I shortened to "popular"
/* Castro Street */ moving two sentences to the next paragraph
/* Tributes */ Since topic sentence is about SF, moving the NYC bit to the last sentence, and tightening

/* Tributes */ wait, I can fix this
/* Aftermath */ I'll say "popularly" because lawyers know better, and I thought the "Moscone and Milk" phrase drew attention away from the Caen quote, which is great
/* White Night riots */ ce (accent marks per [[MWOS]], Wiktionary and WP)
/* Black Monday */ Is "bloodsucking" okay? (the word, not as in [[True Blood]])
/* Briggs Initiative */ avoiding a scuffle over commas, and trimming
/* Briggs Initiative */ "then-former" might sounds to the reader as if he was governor again later. I know a lot of our readers are young, but I hope they've heard of Reagan.
/* Briggs Initiative */ feel free to revert; just a personal preference, but I like the quote better if we lop a half-sentence off
/* Briggs Initiative */ Per [[WP:WORDS]], we're supposed to stay away from "noted", although it wasn't doing much harm here.
/* Supervisor */ feel free to add "campaigns" back in, maybe with a little description of the nature of the campaigns, if you want to
/* Supervisor */ I like "poop" (here, not in general) because it helps to clarify "pooper scooper"
/* Last campaign */ I'm guessing he didn't have authority to pick his successor, only who he wanted to see as his successor
/* Last campaign */ Gonna go with [[AP Stylebook]] here
/* Last campaign */ feel free to revert, but I think their activity was directed at ordinances
/* Just politics */ Per [[WP:CAPTION]], captions should be even more succinct than the article text.
/* Just politics */ We could perhaps prove that there was a certain standard that the police didn't meet, but I don't see the proof here. Can we say their response was considered inadequate?
/* Just politics */ We can't really know that he never said something
/* Just politics */ the word "outlaw" has a colorful history, "ban" is more boring but clearer
/* Just politics */ ce; I also moved the Minn - Saint Paul page per [[WP:NCGN]] and [[WP:DASH]]
/* Race for state assembly */ her mother didn't really order her not to, just tried to persuade her to do some more age-appropriate
/* Just politics */ Feel free to revert; this expresses my take on it, which I'm guessing the sources reflect
